author: Business Wire
title: Life Is Chill Expands Line of THC Soft Gels with New Live Resin THC Capsules, A First Of Its Kind for the Arizona Market | dailytimesleader.com | Serving West Point & Clay County Since 1867
text:
The new plant-based soft gel will launch on Friday, January 19, providing Arizona consumers with a unique and innovative capsule option.
Ally Biotech, dba Life Is Chill, a science-based provider of leading-edge bioactive delivery solutions for cannabinoids, today announces the launch of its live resin soft-gel capsules, ResinTime, under its Life Is Chill product line. The initial offering to the market is vegan-friendly, a new innovative soft gel based on a tapioca-starch and sugar-free product that addresses some of the dietary needs of consumers. The launch of live resin capsules marks a new era for soft gels in the Arizona market and will meet the increasing demand for products made from fresh-frozen cannabis.
â€œCapsules are an increasingly popular choice for those seeking a smoke-free and sugar-free product, but the common practice of using gelatin in pills makes them inaccessible to people who prefer plant-based products or people that have allergies to bovine gelatin,â€ said Francis Baczek, President at Life Is Chill. â€œOur newest addition to the Chill Pill product line solves this problem with the additional benefit of high-quality live resin.â€
The ResinTime soft gels will officially launch on January 19th, 2024, at The Superior Dispensary in Phoenix. The vegan-friendly ResinTime is the company's newest addition to its current portfolio of easy-to-swallow THC soft-gel capsules, which includes six other variations: Day Caps, Night Caps, Anytime Caps, Anytime Hybrid+, Extreme Caps, and THCa Caps.
â€œWe are honored to kick off the launch of these live resin soft gels, a first of its kind in the Arizona market,â€ said Steve Shapiro, founder and CEO of The Superior Dispensary. â€œAs a vegan, Iâ€™m excited to have a vegan-friendly product available for consumers. These capsules will provide another great option for customers seeking new ways to consume live resin-based products in an easily digestible way.â€
The award-winning soft gel brand is available in dozens of dispensaries across the state and has cemented itself as an Arizona staple for almost a decade. With the global cannabis capsule market expected to reach $108.14 billion by 2029, according to Data Bridge Market Research, and at least 6% of the American population identifying as either vegetarian or vegan, this new launch will meet the growing demand for dietary-friendly live resin products and provide an inhalation-free and sugar-free method of consumption for Arizona cannabis users.
The new product launch follows Ally Biotechâ€™s acquisition of the Chill Pill line in the spring of 2023. It continues the companyâ€™s plan to expand its product line and establish itself as a market leader in the soft gel category. For more information about the Chill Pill, visit Lifeischill.com.
About Life Is Chill:
The Arizona-based Life Is Chill brand is an expansive line of easy-to-swallow THC soft gels for the cannabis industry. Formulated using hemp seed oil, Chill Pills are sugar-free, easy to absorb and metabolize, and come in various strengths and strains, with effects ranging from highly responsive to highly relaxed. Life Is Chill is owned and operated by Ally Biotech, a company committed to harnessing the power of science to create innovative THC products. For more information, visit Lifeischill.com .
About Ally Biotech:
Headquartered in Payson, Arizona, Ally Biotech manufactures highly bioavailable products. The companyâ€™s LipofusionÂ® delivery technology combines nanotechnology and liposomal science to speed product differentiation and innovation. The companyâ€™s products undergo rigorous testing for purity, potency, safety, and efficacy at third-party laboratories. For more information, visit AllyBiotech.com . For more information about the Life Is Chill brand, please visit Lifeischill.com.

author: Gerardo GarcÃ­a
title: CÃ³mputos distritales y municipales revierten triunfos en elecciones en Edomex | El Heraldo de MÃ©xico
text: A 24 horas de iniciar los cÃ³mputos para conocer los resultados oficiales en [elecciones a alcaldÃ­as](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/elecciones/2024/6/4/candidatos-de-fuerza-corazon-por-el-edomex-en-toluca-tlalnepantla-desconocen-los-resultados-del-ieem-609542.html) y diputaciones mexiquenses, el ejercicio o el recuento total de votos ha incidido en revertir triunfos entre Morena y el bloque aliancista en Luvianos y Otumba, el primero pasÃ³ a Morena y aliados, y el segundo al PRI y aliados, que junto a 16 demarcaciones arrojaban contiendas cerradas. En Luvianos ahora serÃ¡ gobernado por el bloque oficialista con Edder Jaimes GarduÃ±o. Este municipio tenÃ­a una diferencia menor del uno por ciento entre los primeros lugares, igual que en Almoloya de JuÃ¡rez, San Mateo Atenco, JocotitlÃ¡n, San SimÃ³n de Guerrero, Hueypoxtla y Villa de CarbÃ³n, donde quedaron firmes los resultados. En tanto, en Otumba serÃ¡ encabezado por el PRI y aliado con HilariÃ³n Coronel Lemus. Dicha contienda tenÃ­a una diferencia de menos dos por ciento entre los primeros lugares, como en San Felipe del Progreso, TexcaltitlÃ¡n, Otzolotepec, Nopaltepec, Tenancingo, Tenango del Aire y Teoloyucan, donde a excepciÃ³n del primero que falta concluir resultados, los demÃ¡s no cambiaron los ganadores. AdemÃ¡s, en las contiendas de Ocoyoacac, Soyaniquilpan y Temascalcingo, en las que la diferencia entre los primeros lugares era de 1.5, tambiÃ©n se ratificaron los triunfos. El Ã¡rbitro electoral mexiquense informÃ³ un avance entre 80 por ciento y 90 por ciento en el conteo en los [consejos municipales](https://adm.heraldodemexico.com.mx/nacional/2024/6/3/resultado-de-las-elecciones-en-el-estado-de-mexico-quien-va-ganando-las-presidencias-municipales-prep-605574.html) y distritales, respectivamente, de sus 170 Ã³rganos desconcentrados. Sigue leyendo: [Morena en Edomex confirma que tendrÃ¡ mayorÃ­a calificada en 62 Legislatura y ofrece consensos](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/elecciones/2024/6/5/morena-en-edomex-confirma-que-tendra-mayoria-calificada-en-62-legislatura-ofrece-consensos-609833.html) [Edomex arranca con cÃ³mputos para resultados electorales finales, hay 7 elecciones cerradas](https://heraldodemexico.com.mx/elecciones/2024/6/5/edomex-arranca-con-computos-para-resultados-electorales-finales-hay-elecciones-cerradas-609787.html) Aunque se registran retrasos en Toluca, Tlalnepantla y Ecatepec, al que se mandaron tres grupos de 12 personas, cada uno, para tener avances esta misma tarde. Y en los casos donde cambiaron de sede San SimÃ³n de Guerrero habÃ­a terminado con los trabajos y en Zumpango y CuautitlÃ¡n Izcalli avanzaban, caso contrario con Zinacantepec y San Felipe del Progreso, que aÃºn faltaban. En la madrugada concluyeron los recuentos totales de las elecciones de Luvianos, Hueypoxtla, JocotitlÃ¡n, Villa del CarbÃ³n y Soyaniquilpan, donde en primer caso el triunfo cambio a favor de la alianza de Morena y aliados con Edder JesÃºs Jaimes GarduÃ±o y mandÃ³ a segundo lugar a PRI y aliados con Iracema HernÃ¡ndez MartÃ­nez. Asimismo, con los cÃ³mputos municipales tambiÃ©n hubo cambios en Otumba donde de acuerdo con el conteo preliminar el primero y segundo lugar tenÃ­an una diferencia de votos de menos del dos por ciento, y los votos nulos eran 578. Con ello, ganÃ³ la alianza â€œFuerza y CorazÃ³n por el Estado de MÃ©xicoâ€, HilariÃ³n Coronel Lemus y perdiÃ³ Morena con Adolfo GodÃ­nez MÃ©ndez. IEEM reconoce cambios en los resultados electorales con cÃ³mputos distritales La consejera presidenta del Instituto Electoral del Estado de MÃ©xico (IEEM), Amalia Pulido GÃ³mez, reconociÃ³ que se han modificado los resultados con los cÃ³mputos o con el recuento total de votos, aunque llamÃ³ a esperar un reporte general. Si hay algunos, la verdad hay algunos resultados que estaban muy cerrados, entonces sÃ­ puede haber algunas diferencias habÃ­a lugares estos justamente el de los recuentos que habÃ­a un punto porcentual de diferencia o menos esa es la causal de la ley para que haya un recuento totalâ€, expresÃ³. El representante electoral de Morena, JosÃ© Francisco VÃ¡zquez RodrÃ­guez, confirmÃ³ que ganaron Luvianos y que perdieron Otumba; sin embargo, proyectÃ³ que pueda ganar otros cinco municipios mÃ¡s, donde cabe recordar que este partido y aliados sumaron 88 demarcaciones. IndicÃ³ que esperarÃ¡n a los resultados finales, pero adelantÃ³ que podrÃ¡n presentar recursos en al menos dos municipios donde la diferencia es de apenas 1.5 por ciento. Estamos ganando mÃ¡s municipios, creo que estaremos hablando de otros cuatro o cinco municipios, tambiÃ©n hemos tenido bajasâ€, expresÃ³. Hay que esperar esos tiempos, creemos que sÃ­ hay una diferencia de 1.5 que traemos dos municipios asÃ­, tendremos que hacer las impugnacionesâ€. La consejera presidenta del IEEM, Pulido GÃ³mez reconociÃ³ que los partidos y candidatos tienen derechos a inconformarse sobre los resultados finales y podrÃ¡n impugnar, pero aclarÃ³ que como Ã¡rbitro electoral estÃ¡n cuidando el voto de la ciudadanÃ­a. Nuestro sistema electoral prevÃ© justamente la existencia de los tribunales electorales que ellos ya resolverÃ¡n sobre estos casos particularesâ€, concluyÃ³.

author: La Gaceta
title: Tormentas en TucumÃ¡n: BurruyacÃº sufriÃ³ las lluvias mÃ¡s intensas
text: Durante la tarde noche de ayer y la madrugada de hoy, Defensa Civil confirmÃ³ que las fuertes lluvias y rÃ¡fagas de viento afectaron diversas zonas de TucumÃ¡n, con un impacto notable en BurruyacÃº, donde se registraron 60 milÃ­metros de agua caÃ­da. Esta localidad, en la zona de El CajÃ³n y San Vicente, fue la mÃ¡s afectada por las precipitaciones, segÃºn precisÃ³ Fernando Torres, titular de Defensa Civil y miembro del ComitÃ© de Emergencia de la provincia. â€œEntramos en alerta naranja ayer en la tarde hasta la medianoche, con lluvias intensas en Ã¡reas del pedemonte y las sierras de BurruyacÃºâ€, explicÃ³ Torres. Estas condiciones climÃ¡ticas llevaron a Defensa Civil a desplegar operativos en varias zonas afectadas por las rÃ¡fagas de viento, particularmente en el sur de la provincia. RÃ¡fagas de viento y caÃ­da de Ã¡rboles En localidades como Santa Ana, La Cocha y TafÃ­ Viejo, el temporal provocÃ³ caÃ­das de Ã¡rboles, aunque sin reportes de personas lesionadas. El sur provincial, en particular, sufriÃ³ cortes de energÃ­a elÃ©ctrica debido al desplome de tendido elÃ©ctrico en zonas como Chicligasta, Graneros y la capital tucumana, donde la empresa distribuidora trabaja en la restauraciÃ³n del servicio. Torres asegurÃ³ que, hasta el momento, no se han reportado situaciones de anegamiento ni evacuaciones, de acuerdo con los informes de las Ã¡reas de Defensa Civil en las zonas afectadas.

author: @ABC21WPTA
title: Local I&M crews helping to restore power in hurricane damaged communities
text: Local I&M crews helping to restore power in hurricane damaged communities FORT WAYNE, Ind. (WPTA) - Many communities have been left without power in the wake of Hurricane Helene. Some local Indiana Michigan Power crews have been sent out to help those affected by the storm. â€œWe were called into action last Friday,â€ says Jesse LaFramboise and Erik Schlemmer. Theyâ€™re just two of the more than 400 who were sent to work in areas of Virgina, Tennessee and Kentucky. LaFramboise says, â€œI know everybodyâ€™s seen it on tv the pictures, probably TikTok, when youâ€™re out here in person, and you see the damage from the flooding, the wind damage, the trees, especially out here in Virgina with the mountains, itâ€™s really heartbreaking.â€ They explained crews are out there sometimes for 16 hours. LaFramboise says, â€œFor everybody here, even though theyâ€™re tired, theyâ€™re finding that extra energy to get everyone back in power.â€ But thereâ€™s one thing they didnâ€™t expect to see while they were working. LaFramboise says, â€œI canâ€™t believe the community is in such high spirits with the devastation Iâ€™ve seen. The people have been nothing but gracious, kind, asking us, which is unbelievable, if we need anything from them. Asking us if weâ€™re hungry, need anything to drink, showing and telling us where the damage is.â€ Theyâ€™re glad theyâ€™ve been able to restore a bit of normalcy in the community. After they got some towns back up and running, LaFramboise says, â€œYou could start to see the lights come on in the community and they started driving by honking their horns and they were actually able to play a football game the night after.â€ As of right now there is still a lot of damage, theyâ€™re working to clean up. I&M crews still donâ€™t know when theyâ€™ll be able to return home. Copyright 2024 WPTA. All rights reserved.

author: Smithsonian Magazine
title: Overdue Book Returned to Colorado Library After 105 Years
text: Overdue Book Returned to Colorado Library After 105 Years The Fort Collins library waived the fine, which totaled over $14,000 when adjusted for inflation On February 13, 1919, a reader in Colorado checked out [Ivanhoe](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/82/82-h/82-h.htm), Walter Scottâ€™s historical romance novel, from the Fort Collins Public Library and Free Reading Room. A few months ago, the book was finally returned to the libraryâ€” [now named](https://blog.poudrelibraries.org/2024/04/century-overdue-library-book-returned-to-poudre-libraries/) the Poudre River Public Library Districtâ€”105 years after its due date. â€œIt came to us from an unnamed woman who [got it from] from her brother, who found it in their momâ€™s belongings in Kansas,â€ Annaclaire Crumpton, the libraryâ€™s digital communications specialist, tells Jennifer Meckles of the local TV station [KUSA](https://www.9news.com/article/features/poudre-libraries-book-returned-105-years/73-fa564604-b617-4c1b-befa-edd64e2ed31e). The bookâ€™s inside back cover holds the original due date slip, which shows that it was checked out just three times before its disappearance. The inside front cover features a slip displaying its [accession number](https://www.archives.gov/research/catalog/lcdrg/elements/accession.html), which was assigned to the book when the library acquired it, and the libraryâ€™s lending rules. According to the rules, â€œA fine of two cents per day shall be collected on all books. If a messenger be sent for a detained book an additional charge of 25 cents shall be collected.â€ Under this system, the fine would now be approximately $760, or about $14,000 when adjusted for inflation, writes Katie Auman, the libraryâ€™s communications and development director, for the [Poudre Libraries blog](https://blog.poudrelibraries.org/2024/04/century-overdue-library-book-returned-to-poudre-libraries/). â€œItâ€™s been annotated and well-lovedâ€”so you wonder how many generations it went through, how many parents to kids,â€ Crumpton tells KUSA. Luckily for the unknown reader who checked out the book, the library stopped enforcing overdue materials fines in [November 2020](https://read.poudrelibraries.org/events/fine-free.cfm). Ivanhoe was not the first decades-overdue book recovered by the Colorado library. In 2019, a book was [returned](https://blog.poudrelibraries.org/2019/03/this-ones-nearly-40-years-overdue/) in the mail 40 years after its due date. The text, Working With Stained Glass by Jean Jacques Duval, had been checked out in October 1978. Although it was returned before the termination of overdue fines, the library dismissed the charges, which, when calculated at the 2019 rate of $0.10 per day, totaled almost $1,500. Fort Collinsâ€™ library system has a rich history dating back to 1882, when citizens established a community reading room. In 1900, it became Coloradoâ€™s sixth public library. [WCVB](https://www.wcvb.com/article/overdue-library-book-returned-after-105-years/60485470)â€™s Jocelyn Brumbaugh reports that the libraryâ€™s staff hopes the overdue Ivanhoe can be displayed at a local history museum or in a special space at the library. In other parts of the countryâ€”and the worldâ€”libraries have received books that had been missing for even longer periods. Just last year, a university received a donation that included a copy of James Clerk Maxwellâ€™s An Elementary Treatise on Electricity that was [nearly 120 years overdue](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/07/09/us/massachusetts-overdue-book-119-years.html) at a library in Massachusetts. Meanwhile, the record for the [worldâ€™s most overdue library book](https://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/67353-most-overdue-library-book) belongs to an obscure German text borrowed from the University of Cambridgeâ€™s [Sidney Sussex College](https://www.sid.cam.ac.uk/worlds-most-overdue-library-book) around 1667 or 1668. A professor stumbled across the volume and returned in 1956, nearly 300 years after it went missing.

organizations.name: fort collins public library and free reading room

author: ConservativeMind
title: Consuming more protein may protect patients taking anti-obesity drug from muscle loss
text:
Women and older adults taking the anti-obesity drug semaglutide may be at higher risk for muscle loss, but higher protein intake may help prevent muscle loss in these patients, according to a small study.
Losing muscle (or lean mass) is a common side effect of weight loss in adults with obesity and may negatively affect metabolism and bone health. This is because muscle helps control blood sugar after meals and plays an important role in keeping bones strong, according to Melanie Haines, M.D.
Approximately 40% of weight lost from taking semaglutideâ€”a type of weight-loss medication known as a GLP-1â€”comes from lean mass, including muscle. It is not yet known who is at highest risk for muscle loss, Haines said.
The researchers studied 40 adults with obesity for three months. Of these patients, 23 were prescribed semaglutide, while 17 followed a diet and lifestyle program for weight loss called Healthy Habits for Life (HHL). The researchers evaluated how their muscle mass changed.
Study participants who were prescribed semaglutide lost more weight than those who participated in the diet and lifestyle program, but the percent of weight loss that was lean mass was similar between the two groups.
After accounting for weight loss, the researchers found that in the semaglutide group, being older, female or eating less protein was linked to greater muscle loss. Also in this group, losing more muscle was linked to less improvement in blood sugar (HbA1c levels).
"Older adults and women may be more likely to lose muscle on semaglutide, but eating more protein may help protect against this," Haines said. "Losing too much muscle may reduce the benefits of semaglutide on blood sugar control. This means preserving muscle during weight loss with semaglutide may be important to reduce insulin resistance and prevent frailty in people with obesity."
